newsitem.title: USA: Disney unit wins rights to Crichton novel.
newsitem.headline: Disney unit wins rights to Crichton novel.

text.p: Walt Disney Co's Touchstone Pictures unit Monday said it won the film rights to Michael Crichton's upcoming novel "Airframe".
Under terms of the deal, Crichton will also serve as producer of the film. No directors or writers are currently attached to the project. Financial terms were not disclosed.
Disney is currently developing a film based on Crichton's book, "Eaters of the Dead," with John McTiernen set to direct.

"Airframe," due in bookstores on December 5, is a thriller about a frightening in-flight incident aboard an airplane and the subsequent investigation to find out what happened. The publisher is Alfred Knopf.

Crichton has written several novels that have been made into movies, including "The Andromeda Strain," "The Great Train Robbery," "Congo," "Jurassic Park," "Rising Sun" and "Disclosure." He also wrote "The Lost World," the recently released sequel to the blockbuster "Jurassic Park."
Additionally, Crichton has directed six films, among them "Westworld," "Coma" and "The Great Train Robbery."
